# Cambridge IGCSE™

CANDIDATE NAME

CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 702, 89]]<|/det|>
A student determines the mass of a metre ruler by a balancing method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 482, 120]]<|/det|>
He is using the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 129, 922, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 266, 532, 285]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 146, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 297, 737, 317]]<|/det|>
The student places a circular load on the metre ruler shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 323, 779, 490]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 503, 591, 522]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
Determine the distance \(d\) of the centre of the load from the zero end of the ruler, as shown in Fig. 1.2. Fig. 1.2 is not to scale.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts the position of the metre ruler on the pivot until the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Describe a technique for ensuring that the ruler is as near as possible to being balanced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 240, 180, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 920, 273]]<|/det|>
The student finds that the ruler is as near as possible to being balanced when the pivot is at the \(47.6 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 273, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(a\) of the centre of the load from the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 304, 722, 322]]<|/det|>
Use your value of \(d\) from (a) and the equation \(a = (50.0 \text{cm} - d)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 349, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 380, 895, 413]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 441, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................... cm

The accuracy of the result obtained by this procedure depends on the metre ruler, without a load, balancing with the pivot at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 737, 91]]<|/det|>
A student determines the focal length of a converging lens by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 101, 227, 119]]<|/det|>
illuminated object

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 114, 925, 203]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 215, 532, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 247, 146, 266]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 247, 616, 266]]<|/det|>
The student sets up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 279, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** precaution that must be taken when setting up the apparatus to ensure accurate measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 355, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 386, 146, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 386, 871, 405]]<|/det|>
The student sets the distance \(u\) between the illuminated object and the lens to \(20.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 418, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
He places the screen near the lens and moves the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object is seen on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 181, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 794, 484]]<|/det|>
Describe a technique for obtaining an image that is as sharp as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 588, 180, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 725, 606]]<|/det|>
Measure \(\nu_{1}\), the distance from the lens to the screen on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 618, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\nu_{1} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 465, 667]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 is drawn to 1/10th scale.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 666, 695, 683]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(V_{1}\), the actual distance from the lens to the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 695, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{1} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 712, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 143, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts the position of the lens so that \(u = 40.0 \text{cm}\) and obtains a new value \(V_{2}\) for the distance between the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 112, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
\[V_{2} = ...................................25.1 ................................... \text{cm}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 147, 796, 168]]<|/det|>
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 170, 576, 203]]<|/det|>
\[f_{2} = \frac{uV_{2}}{(u + V_{2})}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 256, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{2} = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 287, 146, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 287, 900, 306]]<|/det|>
Suggest which value of focal length, \(f_{1}\) or \(f_{2}\), might be more accurate. Explain your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 697, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of a liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable her to investigate how changing the thickness of insulation surrounding a beaker affects the rate of cooling of hot water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 182, 282, 198]]<|/det|>
· a glass beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 332, 212]]<|/det|>
· a supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 330, 227]]<|/det|>
· a lid to fit the beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 512, 243]]<|/det|>
· strips of insulation which can be cut to size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 225, 275]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 457, 305]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 918, 352]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the rate of cooling can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 485, 383]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 398, 918, 429]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 603, 460]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 576, 491]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
